interview_questions.question: What is an HTML attribute and how is it used?
interview_questions.answer: An HTML attribute provides additional information about an element and is written inside the opening tag. For example: ```html ```
interview_questions.explanation: Attributes are always defined in the opening tag and usually come in name-value pairs, such as `src="logo.png"`.

interview_questions.question: Give examples of common global attributes in HTML.
interview_questions.answer: Common global attributes include `id`, `class`, `style`, `title`, `hidden`, and `data-*` attributes.
interview_questions.explanation: Global attributes can be used on almost any HTML element to provide identification, styling, data storage, and more.

interview_questions.question: What is the purpose of the `id` attribute in HTML?
interview_questions.answer:
The `id` attribute uniquely identifies an element in the document. Example: ```html

Welcome!

```
interview_questions.explanation: Each `id` value must be unique within the page. It is useful for linking, scripting, and styling.

interview_questions.question: How do you use the `class` attribute and what is its benefit?
interview_questions.answer:
The `class` attribute assigns one or more class names to an element. Example: ```html
```
interview_questions.explanation: Classes are used for CSS styling and JavaScript selection, allowing you to apply styles or behaviors to groups of elements.

interview_questions.question: What are `data-*` attributes and how are they used?
interview_questions.answer:
`data-*` attributes store custom data on any HTML element. Example: ```html
```
interview_questions.explanation: They are used to embed custom, non-visible data for scripts and applications without affecting layout or appearance.

interview_questions.question: Are HTML attribute names case sensitive?
interview_questions.answer: No, HTML attribute names are not case sensitive. Both `CLASS` and `class` are treated the same by the browser.
interview_questions.explanation: However, it's best practice to use lowercase for consistency and readability.

interview_questions.question: Can you use the same attribute multiple times on the same element? Why or why not?
interview_questions.answer: No, you cannot use the same attribute more than once on a single element. The last occurrence will override previous ones.
interview_questions.explanation: HTML parsers use the last value found, which can cause confusion and bugs.

interview_questions.question: How do boolean attributes work in HTML? Give an example.
interview_questions.answer:
Boolean attributes can be written with just the attribute name, without a value. Example:

```html
<input type="checkbox" checked>
```
interview_questions.explanation: If the attribute is present, its value is true, otherwise it is false. Writing `checked="checked"` is also valid.

interview_questions.question: How do you specify the target of a link using attributes?
interview_questions.answer: Use the `target` attribute on the `` tag to control where the link opens. Example: ```html Open in new tab ```
interview_questions.explanation: `_blank` opens the link in a new tab or window. Other values include `_self`, `_parent`, and `_top`.
